characters: SPONSORED BY THE BELHATCHETT BANK OF AUSTRALIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC - string violins treat us to a familiar song openin and then a voice - male.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winds in the East Mist coming in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whoosh of wind spins us around in a blue sky, spinning, spinning until we slow to a stop and find ourselves among white fluffy clouds. A shadow (oddly shaped like an umbre dances amongst the nimbus.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Like something is brewing, about to begin-- The shadow's direction becomes purposeful - taking us dow through the clouds, whipping us on the wind towards a sma town in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Can't put me finger on what lies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downwards and downwards until it skittishly circles a lar bustling park and then swoops us into the lavish gardens. There, a ten-year-old girl plays in the lush grass; she p the finishing touches to a miniature version of the large park she sits in - benches made from twigs, trees from flowers, picnic cups from acorns - and gives a satisfied She wraps her arms tightly around her chest, lifts her fa to the sky, a half-smile threatening to break across her concentrated face. This is the young P.L. TRAVERS (whom w will also know as GINTY.)

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --But I feel what's to happen, all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her little brow is furrowed with imagination and then, al a sudden, the smile breaks free as something in her mind becomes real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.L. TRAVERS sits in her rocking chair (in the same posit as above) arms clasped tightly around her body, face to t sky. Older, beautiful; striking blue eyes aid her air of stiff and steely determination. Her office is a canvas of a life well travelled. Buddha smiles from every corner, framed poetry and letters adorn walls alongside pictures of Pamela throughout the years w men we will not come to know and everywhere, china hens s on shelves, their wings clasped to their chests, brooding Despite the multitude of objects, the room is peaceful, white. Downstairs the doorbell rings. Pamela closes her eyes, breathes. It rings again, Pamela shakes her head, tuts. She stands smooths down her skirt with flat palms. Breathes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela opens the front door and squints as a flood of sunlight and cherry blossom petals float over the thresho DIARMUID RUSSELL (45) - bright, youthful - waits to be as inside. Pamela is not pleased to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela and Diarmuid sit in silence. Diarmuid looks at her she looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ready to--? Like pink clouds on sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cherry blossoms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to think of what they-- Diarmuid looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car should be here, may I use--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cancelled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Pamela!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers, please, why-- (sugaring his tone) Why would you cancel the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shan't be going. Diarmuid buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been through this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect Mr Russell I am on very good terms with my own faculty and exceedingly confident in its decision making capabilities. Diarmuid's shoulders visibly sag, he lets out a long frustrated breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made an agreement. Do you understand? A verbal agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the world are you speaking to me as if I am a neonate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll what? Sue? He is most welcome to every penny I don't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I've represented you for a long time. I like to think of you as a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela snorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to think of it, believe me I know it's not reciprocated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never suggest you do something that would cause you anguish but there's no more money Pamela-- Mrs Travers. Simply no more. Sales have dried up, no more royalties. You refuse to write further books so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand? I'm frightened that you don't understand what that means. Pamela looks out of the window, the cherry blossom her fo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what he's going to do to her- - she'll be cavorting and twinkling! Careening towards a happy ending like a kamikaze--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --We've been trying to do this deal for twenty years! He's agreed to both your stipulations. No animation, script approval-- I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use her to pay my bills? If I believed in a hell I'd be sitting in its waiting room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --script approval! He's never granted anything like that before! I don't know what else to-- He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Polly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fired her. Diarmuid shakes his head, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just as well. It seems I can't afford her anymore anyway! Pamela looks to the ceiling, breathes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how much she means to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not Polly! Pamela huffs, digs her heel into the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's a filthy word) Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have only to go there and work for two weeks. Collaborate. That's it. You haven't signed the rights over, yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must make it work Mrs Travers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I must, must I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need the money. I don't want you to see you-- (broke).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying money! It's a filthy, disgusting word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am picking up the telephone Mrs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diarmuid gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have final say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have final say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I don't like what they are doing to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't sign the papers. He cannot make the film unless you grant the rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an exploratory trip-- Pamela looks at the cherry blossom again, a piece floats from the tree and sticks to her living room window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to keep my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large hand taps Ginty on the shoulder, she looks up and smiles. TRAVERS GOFF (35) is handsome and rugged, a wild poetic look, like Ted Hughes or Dylan Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me ma'am, have you seen my daughter? I was quite sure I had left her around here somewhere! Ginty giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is Helen, no, Shirley, erm- - goodness! I've quite forgotten! Could it be Prunella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right still doesn't sound quite-- I'm sure I have a special name for her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you ma'am! Ginty it is of course!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, have you seen her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me! Travers puts his nose right up to hers, peering into her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh! So it is! Well, thank goodness for that! I was positive I was going to be beheaded for losing Her Highness The Royal Princess Ginty Mc Featherfluffy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't lose me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. I promise. I will never lose you! He swings her up onto his shoulders and gallops off throu the park, neighing like a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry now! We mustn't be late! The adventure is about to begin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela is hot and bothered trying to wrestle a bulging ca bag into an overhead locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly capable thank you. The flight attendant tries to help anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've used all the space; so greedy. She glares at the people around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it Madam. I can put it up here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it up there. I want it here, in the corresponding holding area for my assigned seat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight's closing in just a few moments Ma'am. I'll have to take it. Pamela narrows her eyes at the attendant as if to say `I you.' A woman, with an infant, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can put my bag up front instead. The flight attendant smiles thankfully and replaces the woman's bag with Pamela's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the child be a nuisance? It's an eleven hour flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er-- no, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolly good. Pamela gives her a watery smile and takes the seat next t the window, she looks out at the tarmac. She closes her eyes, takes a deep breath, opens her eyes again and tucks her feet tidily together. She folds her h neatly into her lap and looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we crash. The passenger across the aisle hears her, horrified!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIDDY (3) and MARGARET - the girls mother, delicate, weak stand outside of their lavish red-bricked home. Suitcases bulge at their feet. Margaret breathes a sigh of relief a she sees Travers hurrying towards them, he swings Ginty f his shoulders and plops her on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs a carriage my love? A stroll is a gift! (beat, excited) Everybody ready? GINTY & BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yep! Margaret takes her youngest child MOYA (1) from the nanny TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along my team! We mustn't miss the train. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her staff) Thank you so much. For everything. GINTY (TO NANNY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you soon Katie Nanna! She picks up her own case; Katie Nanna turns away, heartbroken. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking bus! The family get into line, one behind the other, Travers i the lead. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget Andrew! Ginty takes Andrew's leash, her own case and somehow help her sister too. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready? And off we go! Passersby tut and shake their heads at the noisy display Travers and the girls march down the street. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left, right, left, right! Coming through! Margaret stays for a beat, longingly taking in and storin picture of the home she leaves behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The procession continues into the bustling downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hectic as tickets are purchased and a CLERK marks a chalkboard with destinations and mileage. Ginty stops, lo at the list. The last city is-- GINTY ALLORA--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Great Western Queensland train chugs its way Westward from the verdant green of Maryborough toward the brown ca of Allora.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBOROUGH
dialogues.text: As it disappears. Ginty stands on the last train platform watching her home, her past, fade into the distance. Ginty's face speaks resignation as it, and the train, rec as billowing white smoke and dust fill the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela jolts in her seat, her eyes flit open. She's distu by her dreams, she flicks her hand in front of her face a somehow batting the memories away. She sighs loudly and d her heel into the carpet of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleary eyed Pamela carries her two bags into the arriva area. She's immediately hit by dazzling sunlight and a se signs bearing the names of various passengers and compani she scans Paramount, Warner Brothers, MGM, finally fallin upon her own name - P.L. Travers - underneath "Walt Disne Presents". PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh does he indeed? She approaches the uniformed driver (RALPH - Mickey Mouse his lapel) who bursts into a beaming smile. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers? P.L. Travers? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, Mrs P.L. Travers! Welcome to the City of Angels. Pamela sneers. He grabs her bags. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take those. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly capable of-- Oh, nevermind. Ralph ushers Pamela through the doors--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and into the sunlight. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun came out to say hello just to you. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be preposterous. Pamela sniffs the air. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smells. Like-- RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasmine. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --chlorine and sweat. Ralph chuckles. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dreadful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shiny black, tinted windowed limo cruises up La Ciene Blvd, passing all kinds of monstrous architecture and gar billboard advertising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela is diminutive on the back seat of the sprawling ca She eyes the champagne on ice, the flutes clinking in the car bar. PAMELA (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absurd. Ralph looks at her in the rearview. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay back there Mrs P.L. Travers? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Mrs P.L. It's just Mrs-- Oh, it's so hot. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problemo! We got a brand new air conditioning system, Missus; cool you right down in no time. Just about make you feel like you're in good old Engerland again! Things they can put in cars these days-- (he shakes his head in AMAZEMENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh almighty. Pamela presses her fingers to her temples. She looks arou finds a button, pushes it and the screen rises between passenger and driver miraculously relieving her of Ralph' natter. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy as a clam) No problemo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With its pink facade and flag flying turrets the hotel resembles a candy castle simmering under a midday sun. The limo glides into the forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A porter opens the door to Pamela's suite and places her belongings on a luggage stand in the hallway. PORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to unpack for you ma'am? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unpack? PORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To take your items from their cases and hang them in the wardrobe ma'am. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, if it is your wish to handle ladies garments I suggest you take employment in a launderette. The porter has no idea what to say, he hovers at the door PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? His eyes flick to his empty palm and back to Pamela. She closes the door on him. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odd. She turns and for the first time takes in-- PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my. --The LUDICROUS suite she has been assigned; it is opulen beyond imagine but it's classy decor has been rather diminished by the array of Disney gifts splattered across every surface of the room. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no, no. Disney Flowers, Disney champagne, Disney exotic fruit baskets, Disney chocolates, Disney posters, cuddly Donald Pluto and Minnie toys and - taking up the entire bed - th BIGGEST stuffed Mickey Mouse imaginable. Imagine it. Nope

dialogues.speaker: BIGGER
dialogues.text: Pamela cannot contain her horror. She stares at it in dis for a moment, and then her eyes fall upon three pears in fruit basket. She stops still for a second before rushing over and picking them out. She turns them over in her han before an enormous wave of panic washes over her. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to the pears) This won't do. She throws open the balcony doors for fresh air and is greeted with dry arid heat, dust, dazzling sunlight--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Arid heat, dazzling sunlight. Travers, Margaret and the children climb stand in a line at the top of a pathway. F their perspective all there is to see is a cloud of swirl red dust; it obscures and then gradually reveals her new home. The surrounding land yellow and burnt - unlike the greens of Maryborough. The house is ramshackle and meagre A swayback white nag wanders near a solitary tree and a f skinny chickens strut about the porch. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A palace! Complete with mighty steed. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And chickens. MARGARET OH--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers puts an arm around her shoulder. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll build beautiful memories here my angel. Margaret offers him a trusting smile. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Travers takes Ginty and Biddy's hands and they run toward their new home. The chickens scatter. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the distance) --in this house you get to share a bedroom! Margaret looks at the surrounding area, there's simply nothing but barren land and red dust for miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDERWATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPLOSH! A green bomb disturbs the tranquil surface and th another SPLOSH! We rise through the water to see Pamela on her balcony throwing the pears, one by one, into the swimmer-free swimming pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good riddance. She breathes a sigh of relief and closes the balcony door PAMELA (CONT'D) (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first things first. She gathers up the Disney paraphernalia and shoves it all a closet. She picks up her bags and goes through to the bedroom whe the BIGGEST stuffed Mickey Mouse imaginable takes up the entire bed. Imagine it. Nope. BIGGER! PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord. Pamela drops her bags, grabs Mickey and places him on the floor, facing the wall. PAMELA (CONT'D) (TO MICKEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can stay there until you learn the art of subtlety. Pamela opens her carpetbag and begins to unpack. She take from it a bottle of pills, which she places on her night stand, followed by another bottle and another and another The potions keep coming, as do creams and books and make- the bag is endless. Things, things and more things come streaming out of it and once the night stand is full she windowsills and any other available surface for her minia Buddhas. Finally she takes out an impossibly large framed picture of herself. She holds it up, admires it, takes do an existing painting and replaces it with her own image. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Pamela is restless, she looks around the room, stands in front of a full length mirror, admiring herself. She turn her face slightly to catch it at its best angle. She lean forward and explores the contours of her face, surprising unlined for a woman of her years. She smiles, full of van PAMELA (CONT'D) (SATISFIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (answering an imaginary QUESTION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, I don't suppose I do mind. She laughs, but Pamela finds joy difficult so it comes ou an ugly snort. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, really! Flatterer! (then scolding herself) Silly girl. She turns her attention away from the mirror and picks up remote control staring at it with bemusement. She points at the television hitting random buttons until suddenly t TV bursts into life. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! She clicks again, the TV goes off, again and it's on. A housewife advertises dish soap with glee, as if dish soap the greatest thing ever invented. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap for the brains. She changes the channel and stares blankly at a man on a black and white screen. It takes a moment before she real that staring back at her is the charming, moustached, kin face of WALTER ELIAS DISNEY (58) on The Wonderful World o Disney Show. Pamela raises an eyebrow-- PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well-- There you are.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: Walt is ringing a little bell but no sound comes out. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry! There's nothing wrong with your television set. This is a pixie bell, the sound is much too high for human ears. Tinkerbell flies into shot. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh there you are Tink! She covers Walt in fairy dust. WALT (CONT'D) (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Get that stuff off of me! (TO AUDIENCE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a little sprinkling of fairy dust can make you fly! Pamela can't help but be drawn in for a tiny moment and t just as quickly, narrows her mistrusting eyes at Walt and switches him off. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off! That's how we deal with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tray of untouched dinner sits outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela lies in bed awake, staring at the ceiling, she sha her head - trying to free it of whatever is trapped in th The moonlight casts a shadow of Mickey on the wall beside bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela waits under the hotel awning, dressed immaculately not a hair out of place. The limo pulls up to the curb an Pamela groans as she sees Ralph jovially jump out of the and rush round to open the passenger door. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning Mrs! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Mrs, it's-- Oh, why do I bother? We're just not going to get it right are we? RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it be the same driver every day? RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious to her tone) Yes ma'am! I'm all yours. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun came out again! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say it like you're surprised. Like the sun is particular about whom it appears for. It seems you think that I am responsible for it's miraculous dawning every day. For goodness sake, it's California! RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly is! He gestures for her to get in. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying a British accent) Madame. Pamela grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela tucks her legs in and folds her hands into her lap Ralph climbs into the driver's seat. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as much to herself as RALPH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would so much rather be accountable for the rain. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's sad. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sad is entirely the wrong emotion. I shan't bother explaining why; IT'LL SIMPLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she makes gesture for flying over his head) Zip! RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey dokey. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain brings life! RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does the sun. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet! RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. Ralph starts the engine and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE MEN in suits wave at the limo as it drives through enormous gates of Disney's Burbank Studio and pulls up in very twee forecourt. They are: DON DAGRADI (45) and the SHERMAN BROTHERS, ROBE (34), he leans on an old worn cane and RICHARD (31), who a bright, sunny, almost cartoon-ish face. Don opens the car door for Pamela and puts out a hand to her from the vehicle but she pushes it away. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela! Good morning! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so discomfiting to hear a perfect stranger use my first name. Mrs Travers. Please. The Sherman's look at each other. Uh oh. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do apologize, Mrs Travers. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Don DaGradi, the script writer. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Co-script-writer. I shall certainly be having my say Mr. DiGraydi. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gradi. Wonderful! I welcome it. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If indeed we ever sign off on a script. Bob and Dick flash each other a look. What the fu ? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. Okay, so this is the rest of your team, Dick and Bob Sherman! Music and lyrics. (TO SHERMANS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, this is the one and only Mrs P.L. Travers, creator of our beloved Mary. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppins. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins. Never ever just Mary. (to Dick and Bob) A pleasure to meet you, though I fear we shan't be acquainted for too long. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These books simply do not lend themselves to chirping and prancing. No. Certainly not a musical. Now, where is Mister Disney? I'd very much like to get this started and finished as briskly as is humanly possible. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don? DICK PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a music--? If you'll point me in his direction?  DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-- erm. Ha! We had planned a little tour of the studio for you MRS TRAVERS-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Wanted to show the place off. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one likes a show off. Pamela takes herself off in the direction of a building. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Trav-- it's a long way to-- Don hurries behind her, Bob looks like he is about to mur the woman and Dick is finding the whole thing incredibly amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shermans, Don and Pamela are riding through the studi on a golf buggy. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am perfectly capable of walking. A couple of Disney characters (Donald and Goofy) bounce u the golf cart, waving brightly. Goofy opens his arms to Pamela for a hug and she recoils in horror. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoo! Go away! The characters stop bouncing and Di Gradi gives them a no meaning `beat it'. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghastly. Bob and Dick Sherman are in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don leads Pamela into the plushly appointed outer office, where DOLLY - a young, perky secretary - smiles brightly her. DON (TO DOLLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you let-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over, to Dolly) Would you let Mister Disney know I have arrived please? Dolly loses her smile at the terse tone, nods curtly and picks up the phone. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering into phone) She's here! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word of advice Mrs Travers, if I may. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may. Whether I heed it or not will be another matter entirely. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Uhm. It's just that he can't stand being called Mr Disney. We are all on a first name basis here. (TO DOLLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly! Is he--? We hear a man's cough before a beaming Walt Disney, in th flesh, appears at the end of the corridor, his arms outstretched. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there ya are at last! Pamela gets up, smooths down her skirt, and makes her way serenely towards the man, who rushes down the corridor to greet her. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my dear gal! Pamela is open mouthed. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't imagine how excited I am to finally meet you! Pamela doesn't know what to do with this amount of enthusiasm. She extends a formal hand before he manages t get her in an embrace. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! He squeezes her tight and then lets go. Pamela struggles compose herself, she hasn't been that close to a man in decades! PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hum-- ah. It's an honour, Mister Disney. Disney winces. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, you gotta call me Walt, ya know. `Mister Disney' was my old man. There's a hint of something mournful in the way he says ` man.' WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here! Come here! He links his arm through hers, much to her chagrin, and l her into his interior office past an imposing floor to ceiling cabinet bursting with Academy Awards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at TOMMIE - who mans the second desk. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommie, say hi to the one and only P L Travers! TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there! It's so nice to-- But Pamela has already been whisked through to Disney's personal office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disney's office is tastefully furnished and filled with pictures of his daughters and wife. Framed posters of his films provide splashes of color to the cream walls. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat, sit down. He gestures to a comfy couch in the corner but Pamela tak seat in front of Walt's desk instead, glancing at the sig above it: We Can Make Them Live. Walt perches on the edge the desk, close to her, gazing at her. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, I can't believe it. P.L. Travers, right here, in my office, after all these years-- almost twenty of `em. (shakes his head) Twenty. Long. Years. Pamela narrows her eyes. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish ya coulda' seen me then Pam! As lean as a whippet I was! A race horse! Interestingly, she doesn't pull him up on using her first name and shortening it too! WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, here you are. Look at you! I could eat you up! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be appropriate. He turns a photo of his daughters - Diane and Sharon - to face Pamela. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Diane here was seven years old I-- can I get you a drink? Coffee? Soda? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pot of tea would be most welc-- WALT (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was seven years old and I was walking past her bedroom and there she was on her bed reading to Sharon, and well, they were just giggling their little socks off! (he picks up the phone, presses a button) Tommie, pot of tea please dear-- You're a doll. (he puts the phone down) She's a doll. Anyways I asked them "Girls, what's so funny?" And Diane said to me, "Mary Poppins daddy!" Well, I had no idea what a Mary Poppins was! And then she gave me your book. And by gosh! He stands up and throws his arms in the air to emphasise point. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My imagination was caught on fire! And I mean ON FIRE! And those embers have burned ever since-- as you know.  PAMELA WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Twenty years!  PAMELA WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Twenty. So you keep I've been asking, asking, SAYING-- ASKING--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela stops talking and waits for Disney to calm down. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got old asking. He sits back down on his desk. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a charming story. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About my getting old? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About your daughters. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I suppose it is. (he looks at the picture) They're both women now. Gosh! Can you believe it? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children grow up. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Pam, a man can't break a promise to his kids. No matter how long it takes to keep. No matter how long! You might've kept me dangling all this time but now we gotcha! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha indeed! Mister Disney, if you have dangled then it is at the end of a rope you have fashioned for yourself. WALT PAMELA-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was quite clear when you approached me the first time that she wasn't for sale and clear again when you approached me a year later and clear again when you approached me every annum for the subsequent 18 years. Honestly, I feel corralled, ensnared-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, Pam, the last thing I want is to make you feel-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name, if you please, is MRS Travers. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I promised them. That's a fact. You got kids? PAMELA NOT-- WALT (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never, I swear, never broken a promise to either one of my Disney girls. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very honourable of you BUT-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what being a daddy is all about right? PAMELA (DEEP BREATH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This movie isn't just going to make my kids happy. It's going to make ALL kids happy! You see my guys are gonna do things with it that are, well, are revolutionary. He's up again. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVOLUTIONARY,Pam! PAMELA OH DEAR--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela rubs her temples as she watches him fly about the room. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins will literally fly off the pages of your books! The door opens and Tommie comes in with the tea, Walt gestures for her to bring it to him. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now imagine! This magical woman who has only lived in your head, you'll be able to meet her, speak to her, hear her sing. Tommie places the tray on Walt's desk and leaves the room Walt picks up the tea pot. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this singing, I am glad you've come to that. (addressing his tea MAKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk first! Walt puts the pot down immediately like a scolded child a picks up the milk jug, he pours. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Now the tea-- He picks up the pot again and pours the tea. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a spoonful of sugar. He stirs. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean for this film to be a musical? WALT (TAKEN ABACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I absolutely do! He presents her with the cup. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She takes a sip, he waits anxiously to see if his tea is good. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. No, Mister Disney, Mary Poppins does not sing. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes she does! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your books! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't songs! They're recitations. She is not a giddy woman, she does not jig! Singing is frivolous and wholly unnecessary for a governess, an educatress. No. It would just ruin it. Walt is baffled. He takes a sip of tea, it's disgusting, spits it back into his cup surreptitiously, then coughs loudly. Pamela's jaw drops. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have her turned into one of your silly cartoons. Walt takes a sharp breath on `silly' and then plasters th smile back on. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell ya what. You just listen to what my Sherman boys have come up with and if they don't knock your socks off then I'm the King of England. Pamela rolls her eyes. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're the King of England then you shan't exist and knowing the little of you I do; I shouldn't think you would like that very much. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you would. She smirks, as does he. PAMELA (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do quite like Greensleeves. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greensleeves huh? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to think of it. That's a song I wouldn't object to. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greensleeves. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He's not sure if she's playing with him. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, I want you to know that the last thing I would do, the very last thing, is tarnish a story I have cherished. He moves closer to her, takes her hand, she needs it for teacup, it's awkward. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing into her eyes) The pages are worn down to tissue, dog eared and falling out. I have poured over them gripped, tormented. Because I love Mary Poppins, you got to share her with me. Pamela is torn between finding Disney captivating and tot barking. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A course nothing happens without your say so. Absolutely Nothing. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right. She extricates her hand. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all in the rights agreement. As approved by your agent, Dermot. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diarmuid. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darmitt. Disney hands the rights agreement and a pen to her, Pamel takes it without looking and folds it up. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving the agreement) A live action film. No animation. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live action. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like that on tape. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your promise-- and all the discussions we have here-- on tape. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tape you say. She pops the rights document in her bag. Walt's joviality his bright demeanour, vanishes in a split second. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah there you are. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins and the Banks's, they're family to me. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I do. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then! She stands up and smooths down her skirt. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we begin? He holds out his hand for her to shake. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make something wonderful. She leaves his hand hanging in mid air. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see if that's at all possible. Pamela gets up, smooths down her skirt, snorts at a pictu of Disney in a silly hat astride a model train and purposefully strides out of the room, a smile across her that Disney does not see. WALT (PERPLEXED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers sits, looking out at the dimming sky, playing a mournful air on his tin whistle, Ginty curled up in his l Andrew the dog asleep beside him. Margaret steps out onto veranda an almost imperceptible glance at the half-empty bottle at his feet. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's rather late-- Travers continues to play. MARGARET (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biddy and Moya are already asleep. Travers takes the pipe from his lips and sighs. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty. He kisses her cheek and gently lifts her from his lap. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night father. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `night mother. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night dear. Margaret strokes her hand over Ginty's hair as the little girl slips into the house but hovers unseen by the door, watching her parents. Travers pats his knee and Margaret perches on it. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make us a good life. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make you proud again. Margaret strokes Travers face and turns her face to the s MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits at a large meeting table as Dolly bustles aro her placing refreshments. Pamela lays out her pencils one one, makes sure her notebook is `just so.' A bowl of fruit is set down upon her notebook and she snatches it away, glaring at the table which is now laden with every type of snack and beverage imaginable from bag to candy, coffee to soda, there are exotic fruits, enormo bouquets of flowers. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering around a vase at DAGRADI)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is all this jollification? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a whole script to get through. It's gonna be a long day Mrs T. She shoots him dead with a killer stare. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --ravers. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could save a starving country with benefaction from this room alone! Ugh, It's so vulgar. She gets up and moves the giant bouquet of flowers off th table and plops it on top of Dick's piano. Bob moves it f the piano to the floor. BOB (SEETHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a very expensive piano. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these are beautiful blooms butchered for our visual and nasal enjoyment when we could have just as easily gone to the window, looked out and gazed upon them happily minding their own business and very much still alive. Bob hasn't a clue what to say. Pamela smoothes down her s and re-takes her seat. Everybody waits. Pamela flicks her eyes at the tape recorder which Don dul turns on. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us begin. She perches her glasses on her nose and raises an eyebrow the cover of her script - "Walt Disney's Mary Poppins." PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. A rustling of papers and one or two uneasy glances as the men, too, open their scripts.

dialogues.speaker: DON DAGRADI PAMELA
dialogues.text: (READING) (READING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene one. Exterior Cherry Scene one. Ext. Ext? What's Tree Lane. London. Day. Bert-- Ext?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick and Bob cover their faces with the embarrassment of all. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior. It means the scene is taking place outside. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I see, an abbreviation. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene One. Exterior-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry Mr DaGradi, did you feel you should--? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, No, Mrs Travers please go ahead. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do think it's best. I've the most practise. Readings of my books you know? Anyway-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene one. Exterior. 17 Cherry Tree Lane, London. Day. She nods. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's good, that can stay. DICK (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just the scene heading! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Though I do think we should say number 17, instead of just 17, yes? It's proper. BOB & DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's going to see it. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see it. She makes a note in her script and looks to the others wh are dumbstruck. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write it down, write it down, chop chop. Don makes the note and is ready to move on but Pamela is staring at Dick and Bob. They dutifully pick up their pen and note their scripts too. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that on the tape? Don glances towards the swirling tape recorder and nods. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-- onwards. They are interrupted by DOLLY carrying a new tray of refreshments. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a joke? DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you are a comedienne? DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I don't understand. Dolly gingerly places the tray on the table and hovers, distributing fruit and biscuits within reachable distance PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. Pamela shakes her head but decides to ignore Dolly and ca on. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene One. Exterior. Number 17 Cherry Tree Lane. London. Day. (MORE) PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, a one-man band-- (she looks up) The rumour is that this is to be your Mister Van Dyke is it? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do hope so! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm, we'll see about that. He's totally wrong, totally and utterly. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick is one of the greats! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Van Dyke? Robert, my dear, Olivier is one of the greats, Burton, Guinness - greats without question. (speaking loudly into the TAPE RECORDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you Dick Van Dyke is not. (back to script) Bert, a one-man band plays to a small gathering outside the gates to the park. (BEAT) BERT SAYS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she looks to Don) You can do Bert. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through gritted teeth) Thank you. (BEING BERT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Ladies and gents, comical poem, suitable for the occasion-- Dick jumps up and sits at the piano. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --extemporized and thought up before your very eyes! Alright, here we go-- Dick begins to play and sing, he pounds the keys with gus smiling away, acting it out with all his heart and soul, almost unable to contain himself with glee. Bob occasiona joins in for a word or two but is much more serious, eyei Travers for her every reaction. DICK (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room here for everyone gather around, THE CONSTABLE'S BOB/DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "responstable." DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, how does that sound? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no no no no no. Dolly winces on everyone's behalf and leaves the room. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Responstable is not a word. DICK (EXCITED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it up! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, un-make it up. Dick quickly hides the next set of sheet music entitled: SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've a thought! I've always liked Ta Ra Ra Boom De Ay. Now, that would be a wonderful song for the film! Oh! And Admiral Boom could sing it! Do you see? Dick's fingers crunch the piano keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela's door opens a crack and another half-eaten room service meal appears as she kicks it into the hallway. Sh shuts the door quickly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela lies awake staring at the ceiling. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irresponstable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny park, about half a metre square - it has grass, ti trees made from flowers, a small hole filled with water f pond, park benches made with twigs and miniature wooden clothes-peg people. Ginty puts the finishing touches to t bandstand and sits back, staring in wonder. The moment is broken with the sound of hooves as her fath appears, atop his horse. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, there's my girl. The horse moves up to her. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it Albert. Give Ginty a smooch. There's a good boy, give her a little smooch. The velvety muzzle of the horse "smooches" Ginty's neck a ear as Travers climbs down from the nag. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor old Albert; he's your secret uncle you know? But a miserable, horrid witch turned him into a nag. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did she do that?! TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she hated the sound of his laugh. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Uncle Albert! How can we fix him? TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to teach the witch how to be happy again. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not quite sure darling. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother's been calling you for a good hour. I shouldn't go if I were you, she's after little slaves for housework! (RECITING YEATS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I must scrub and bake and sweep Till stars are beginning to blink AND PEEP;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the young lie long and dream in THEIR BED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the matching of ribbons for bosom and head. Travers sighs, let's the words ring in his ears, touches end of daughter's nose. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to know what it feels like to fly Ginty? She nods. He hauls himself onto Albert, leans down and sw Ginty up so she is facing him. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trust me? She nods and wraps her arms around him looking backwards his shoulder. He grips her firmly around the waist and she spreads her arms. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee up, Albert. Yah! Travers kicks the horse into a trot, then into a canter, points a finger in the air as if shooting for the stars. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah! Ginty squeals with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela looks out of the window at the palm trees, the emp sidewalks. She looks dazed, extremely tired-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody walks. RALPH (SADLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leisurely stroll's a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo floats along the windy canyon roads, cresting th top of the hill and revealing an awe inspiring vista. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful ain't it? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refusing him the SATISFACTION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like that sort of thing. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers and Ginty gallop at great speed. The horse kickin great clods of earth as they hurtle away into the distanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don DaGradi and the Shermans are escorting Pamela along a of storyboard illustrations for the film. Dolly trundles along behind, carrying a tray with a cup of tea on it whi Pamela occasionally picks up and takes a sip from. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do find it helps to have a visual. It's fun! She stops in front of a sketch of the Banks house. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Goodness no. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Banks house doesn't look like that! My house is a terraced house with a pink door, white bricked with a crack in the gable. The window frames are lead-lined and the flower boxes grow pink nasturtiums to go with the pink DOOR AND--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to the tape RECORDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we get that? (to herself, slightly HYSTERICAL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, it's all a big mistake. It's all wrong. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all wrong? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too grand! The Banks family - they're normal, everyday sort of people. This isn't normal. It isn't everyday! They're not aristocrats! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. Don allows a tiny smile. She is right. Pamela lingers ove picture of the parrot head umbrella, a split second of something like recognition on her face and then she simpl moves on. PAMELA (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She stops again in front of a sketch of Mrs Banks wearing suffragette ribbon. PAMELA (CONT'D) (SIGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I even have to say it? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um-- yeah? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the world have you made Mrs Banks a silly suffragette? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if Emmeline P would agree with that adjective-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite possibly, looking back. Dick mouths `oh my god!' DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does seem strange that Mrs Banks allows her children to spend all of their time with the nanny when she has no job to speak of-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you calling Mrs Banks neglectful? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Of course not! We just felt that if she had a job it would go some way to explaining-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being a mother is a job. A very difficult job and one that not everybody is up to, that not everybody should have taken on in the first place! The boys see that Pamela is talking about something meaningful to her and they begin to soften for a brief moment, until-- PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will NOT have her called Cynthia! Absolutely not. It feels unlucky. Dick makes a curly wurly cuckoo sign at Bob. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it should be something warm, a bit sexy. They all nearly choke at the word `sexy' coming out of he mouth. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Mavis? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sybil? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prudence? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gwendolyn? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winifred! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could go with Winifred. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's because it's very good. She comes to the next sketch and stops abruptly in front it, a split second of utter confusion crosses her face. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't Mr Banks? She turns to face Don and the boys. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't him. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahm, yeah, that's him-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a set of moustaches! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the books he-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the illustrator I didn't like the facial hair but she chose to ignore me. This is MY film and this time around I shall have MY way. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearing her throat) Mrs Travers, it was a specific request, from Walt. Pamela doesn't acknowledge that Dolly has spoken; Dolly flushes. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the boys) Why? Everyone shrugs, they don't know why. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't, he doesn't, Mr Banks is clean shaven! Bob buries his face in his hands and let's out a long, lo unashamed moan. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it mattterrrrrrr?! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, Bob, Bob-- Pamela stares at Bob. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can wait outside! She points at the door, ordering him out with her finger. is literally stunned. Dick stifles a laugh. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shan't say it again Robert. Bob storms out of the room (as fast as his limp and cane allow him) slamming the door and from behind it we hear:

dialogues.speaker: KILL ME
dialogues.text: PAMELA (TO DICK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with his leg? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got shot. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly surprising. Pamela smiles sweetly. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I expect anymore drama from anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela enters the lobby and heads for the elevator. She s the bar, full of people laughing, exclaiming, enjoying on another's company. She takes it in melancholically for a second and then jabs the elevator button repeatedly, reli when the doors finally slide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers faces his reflection in the mirror as Ginty looks from the doorway. He picks up his razor and begins to scr away the stubble. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do that? TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you my dear! (he flicks the blade in the air like a swordsman) Swish! Which kind of kisses do you prefer Gintamina? Swoosh! Scratchy ones or silky ones? GINTY (THINKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silky ones. A man must shave for to spare his daughter's cheeks! Swish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela stares at herself in the clouded bathroom mirror. runs a finger through the steam on the glass. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swish. And again. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swoosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, carrying a tray of cakes, stops at the rehearsal r door where fractious voices ring out.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! Stop! What on earth are you talking about? Supercali--? Supercali-- or whatever the infernal thing is! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's something to say when you don't know what to say! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I always know what to say. The slamming of a piano lid. Dolly pushes the door open w her foot.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: If you so much as step one foot in here with that tray I shall scream! One cannot live on cake alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly stands in Disney's office. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me with it. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a lot of-- ideas. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya? What kind of ideas? DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About how she, uh, sees things. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just how does she `see' things? Dolly sighs and pulls out a note pad. DOLLY (READING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name Cynthia has been changed to Winifred. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay that'll work. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't approve Dick Van Dyke. Walt laughs, Dolly allows herself a little giggle too. DOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sketches of the Banks house make it look too opulent, there must be no hint of romance between Mary Poppins and Bert, she wants to know why Mr Banks has been given a moustache, the-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked for that. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They did tell her but she wants to know why. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I asked for it. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. Uh-- the tape measure Mary Poppins uses to record Jane and Micheal's height must be a roll tape, not a ruler, we must add gravi-- gravitas, she says. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gahd! Anything else? DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She only wants green vegetables and broth, I don't know what that is but she wants it in the room from now on and oh! She doesn't want the colour red in the film-- at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, Don and Pamela sit around the meeting table. Bob ho by the door in a right humph. Disney prefers to stand, grazing occasionally from a bowl of candy. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've simply gone off the colour. Their mouths are agape. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did say I was to have final say did you not? DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't make the film without the colour red! It's set in London for pete's sake. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's buses and mail boxes and guards uniforms-- heck! The British flag! Pamela, I'm not sure why YOU'RE-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your predicament Mr Disney, I do. I just-- hm-- I don't know what it is, I'm just suddenly very anti-red. I shan't be wearing it ever again. Disney comes and sits on the table in front of Pam and lo eyes with her. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a test Pam? Are you requiring proof of how badly I wanna make you happy so that we can create this beautiful thing together? Pamela averts her eyes for a split second, embarrassed ab `creating something beautiful' with Walt, but quickly recovers and eyeballs him right back. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took you at your word Mr Disney and it seems my first stipulation has been denied. There will be many more, so-- perhaps we should just call it quits and I should hand you back these? She takes the rights agreement out of her bag and offers to him. Disney smiles at Pamela. DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. No red in the film. Pamela glances at the tape recorder. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt? Don and the Shermans can't believe he has given in! Disne strides out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disney marches down the corridor away from the rehearsal room. He stops, turns, goes back to the door, puts his ha on the handle, stops himself and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, Don and Bob are left astounded. They look at one another. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have the rights-- All three turn their heads to turn to her. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. Pamela smiles a broad satisfied smile at the boys, smooth down her skirt and opens the script. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, If you're insisting upon this musicality you feel is SO important for my film then I suggest I hear one of your ditties. No one is in the mood to sing for her. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall keep an open mind! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nanny? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, do nanny. Dick begins to play-- BOB (SPOKEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted a nanny for two adorable children. Pamela sighs, so do Don and Bob.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want this choice (expecting Dick to stop) position, No no! They can't make deman-- have a cheery disposition--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dick ignores her and carries on. DICK ROSY CHEEKS-- BOB PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No warts! Who in the world put that in?!

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Play games, all sorts! Hm.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be kind, you must be Well of all the ridiculous- WITTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: very sweet and fairly pretty

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take us on outings, give us Completely defeats the-- TREATS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Don are trying to stop themselves from laughing a Dick barrels right over everything Pamela says, almost as the two of them are doing a duet.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sing songs, bring sweets No sweets!

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never be cross or cruel Who would give a child cast-- Never give us castor oil or ? GRUEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick grimaces (a la Michael Banks.) DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love us as a son and daughter BOB PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And never smell of barley What in the world does water smelling of barley water have to do with anything?  BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote that in your book! She wrote that in her--! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think-- DICK PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over) You can't say that-- If you won't scold and DOMINATE US

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will never give you cause Hate is too strong a wor-- to hate us-- DICK PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't hide your spectacles (into tape recorder) so you cant see Nobody's listening to me!  DICK PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put toads in your bed-- Ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or pepper in your tea No.  DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Nanny! MANY THANKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sincerely, Jane and Michael Banks: Jane and Michael Banks. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I simply don't know what to say. That's the worst song I've ever heard. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt stands looking out of his window. DISNEY POV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits on a bench, her feet tucked together, her arm clasped around her body, her face to the sky. She sits perfectly still until the limo pulls up and Ralph gets ou patiently waiting beside the car so as not to disturb her Pamela, opens her eyes and Ralph nods hello. He opens the back door for her and she climbs in. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommie! Tommie appears in his office with a glass and hands it to Walt. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch Mist. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I think I-- what? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a woman. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a canny observation Walt. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I missing? TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the female of the species has some kind of psychic insight when it comes to others of her kind? Walt continues to stare out of the window. TOMMIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get yourself an ulcer with all that unriddling. Give it up. Tommie waits for a response but he's still window bound, filled with intrigue as he watches the car disappear. WALT (UNDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela enters the lobby and heads for the elevator. She s the bar again, a few people chatting over cocktails. The elevator doors open but she chooses to go and sit at the instead. BARMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon Ma'am. What can I fix you? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pot of tea. BARMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Pamela looks around at the other women in the bar, all glamorous, coiffured, very different to the practical Mrs Travers. The tea pot arrives. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Tea is a balm for the soul don't you agree? But the barman has already moved on to another patron. Time moves swiftly, the teapot is drained, the customers and go. The barman talks with another customer further al the bar. Nobody notices Pamela. In this setting she looks like a little old lady, awkwardly perched on a stool, sta into her empty cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty - in a rather tattered school uniform - is diminuti in front of the huge double doors to the bank. An upright top hatted gentleman holds the door of the bank open chivalrously for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty and the man enter the bank. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. A bank worker tips his hat to the gentleman. BANK WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon Mr Belhatchett. Cashiers look up from their posts and nod courteously. Ginty and RANDOLPH BELHATCHETT are startled for a second loud crash. Their eyes flit to the glass door of Travers' office. The etching on the glass reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers has just dropped (purposefully) a tray of coins o the floor. He has a wild edge to him, he may well have be drinking. TRAVERS (TO CLERK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belhatchett. Bell. Hatchett. Ha! It's a ridiculous moniker! CLERK SIR-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mr Belhatchett has complained that I opened his stupid bank five minutes late has he? Hahaaa! (in a comedy voice) Time's Money, Goff, y'know! Time's money my man! The clerk laughs nervously. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bell Hatchett! Beautiful hatchet. That's what it means. And I suppose if the poor dumb lambs on his downs, are five minutes late with their calving, or they don't drop dead on schedule when he wants a roast, he takes to them with the business end of his beautiful hatchet. Travers wields a glinting letter opener in the air, stabb piles of papers, filing cabinets, desks. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, whack! That'll teach you for not dropping your bairns on schedule. Whack! Whack! Whack! Travers looks at the figure standing outside his door and eyes widen. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whack. Whoops! (through the door) Mr Belhatchett! Allow me to-- Travers pushes the door open to reveal Ginty at his side is felled. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty! RANDOLPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you gone. All eyes fall upon the little girl whom everyone seems to have forgotten. Travers is overcome with embarrassment an guilt. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet thing! What are you doing here? Ginty looks up at Belhatchett and the manager. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said today was-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice cream day! Yes! I did! What kind of father am I? GINTY (SCARED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fired again? TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes it does seem that-- RANDOLPH (TO GINTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No sweetheart-- he isn't. TRAVERS (TO GINTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait in my office for a second darling. Randolph walks away, stopping to whisper in Travers ear. RANDOLPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't straighten up for your own sake. Do it for your daughter. (muttering to himself) Irresponsible. Travers holds out his arms to Ginty and she runs into the TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice cream is so rare because it only comes from Siberian cows. Did you know that?! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brrrrrrrr!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty and Travers sit by the river. Ginty eats an enormou ice cream and Travers sips continuously from his hip flas TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We share a Celtic soul, you and I. This world is just an illusion, Ginty old girl. As long as we hold that thought dear, they can't break us. Money, money, money. Don't you buy into it Ginty! It'll bite you on the bot! How did we end up here eh? Look at it. Barren. Breathless. Get as far away from this place as possible my love. Find yourself a patch of green. (HE SIGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a chimera you know? The world, the bank, you and I, Mr Randolph- whackety-whack-Belhatchett. All an illusion. He stares across the river, experiencing a wave of deep melancholy. Ginty looks up at him, aware of his profound unhappiness, but unable to understand its source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another untouched meal in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela lies in the dark, the phone pressed to her ear. PAMELA (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loathe this place, Mr Russell. How can a place so sunny be so cold? We don't hear what Diarmuid says. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant heartless. I'm afraid a jumper wouldn't suffice. It's bringing up these-- it's so hot and stuffy I feel like I am being attacked. These odd dreams, like my subconscious is after me. Punishing me for entertaining the idea that I might hand her over. I am at war with myself Mr Russell. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The script is ghastly, exactly as I EXPECTED-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, a few more days and then I'll DECIDE-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know I need the money. The money. The money. (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money. It'll bite you on the-- (INTO PHONE)
