dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all an illusion you know Mr Russell? All an illusion. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Good morning and goodnight. She hangs up the phone, and continues sitting upright. Wi awake. Staring into the darkness. Pamela checks through her multitude of pill bottles for something to help her. Nothing. She groans as she drags herself out of bed, pacing the room, counting steps. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serves me right. Money, money, money. Bit me on the bot. Her eyes stray to the big Mickey Mouse. She drags it onto bed with her and climbs back under the covers, clinging o the stuffed toy for comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is decidedly more lively, with sketches of the c and models of the sets all about the place. And of course the requisite abundance of brightly coloured food now accompanied by some healthier options - vegetables and a fluorescent looking soup. Bob and Dick are at the piano. Don sits in the corner, sketching energetically on his notepad what seems to be a cartoon sketch of Pamela Travers. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gotta be like a slogan! BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her prescription for life. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Yes! A stitch in time! BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An apple a day. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from across the room) Time and tide wait for-- BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar? DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? That's not-- BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff had vaccination day at school yesterday. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ouch. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ouch? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar. They put it in a cube. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine in sugar? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cube's an odd word. BOB (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoonful? Dick throws his hands and legs in the air almost falling his stool! DON (UNDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we have sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela steps from the car and Walt is there to greet her. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I walk with you? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure your country doesn't have any laws about sharing a pavement. As they walk the sound of the piano filters out of the rehearsal room window and down onto the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick is playing about with a verse. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to the chorus. DICK & BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing it incorrectly) Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down! BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! WAIT! She always does what's unexpected. She goes UP the bannisters. Dick is confused. BOB (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So go up. Dick plays a high note. BOB (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try B. He takes a pencil from behind his ear and marks Dick's sh music. Dick immediately begins finding the tune on the pi DICK & BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing `down' in an up KEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down. Don looks up from his sketching. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! The sound of Walt's cough signals his imminent arrival. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man is in the forest. Pamela and Walt enter the room. DON (CONT'D) (TO WALT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to hear this. (to the boys) Play him what you got. Walt takes a seat beside the piano. Pamela folds her arms across her chest defiantly. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a chorus-- BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us what you think. He knows dum dum Will help dum dum dum duuuum! Bob whistles what will end up being the Robin's part of t song. DICK (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down-- the medicine go do-own, medicine go down Just a spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down In a most de da dee daaa! BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work out the other lyrics. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how it goes up on the word down? BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the word down it goes up! PAMELA (UNHAPPY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ironic. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget ironic, it's iconic. Pamela rolls her eyes. PAMELA (SARCASTIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be able to stop singing that for weeks! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems enormously patronising to me. The very sort of annoying tune you would have playing in your themed park I daresay. All giddy and carefree, encouraging children to face the world unarmed. All they need is a spoon and some sugar and a brain full of fluff and they're equipped with life's tools. Wonderful! Dick is completely deflated. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your point Pam? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS Travers! My point is that, unlike yourself, Mary Poppins is the very enemy of sentiment and whimsy. She is truthful, she doesn't sugar coat the darkness in the world that these children will eventually come to know. She prepares them for it, she deals in honesty. One must clean one's room; it won't magically do it itself! She waves the script in the air. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole script is flim flam! Where is its reality? Where is its heart, where is the gravitas? She opens a window and flings the script out. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No weight Mister Disney! See? Dick, Don and Bob look out of the window as the pages flu downwards and spread themselves over the Disney lot. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No whimsy or sentiment says the woman who sends a flying nanny with a talking umbrella to save the children. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Mary Poppins is saving the children Mr Disney? Pamela sighs, shakes her head. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela makes her way to the bench she waits on for Ralph. She sits down, wraps her arms around herself, closes her eyes. PAMELA (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret sweats as she hangs out laundry whilst desperate shushing her screaming infant. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There there. Shush shush now-- Ginty and Biddy run in and out of the sheets, chasing a l hen that squawks and flaps its wings trying to escape the girls. MARGARET (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the girls) If you could just-- TRAVERS (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahoy Goffs! The girls and Margaret look up, surprised to see Travers early. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father! She runs at him and swings her high into the air with one arm, catching Biddy with the other. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a lovely surprise! Did you finish early? TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't stop thinking about my beautiful girls on this beautiful day in this beautiful place and I thought to hell with it! (to Ginty and Biddy) And what do we say about beauty ladies?

dialogues.speaker: GINTY/BIDDY/TRAVERS
dialogues.text: A thing of beauty is a joy forever! MARGARET BUT-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buts are for goats my love! He dips her and smooches her. GINTY & BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urgh! TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Margaret) I'll put in extra hours tomorrow. (TO GINTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we playing? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hen got out and we've been trying to catch her! Travers spies the clucking demon. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no hen! That's Aunt Ellie, your mother's horrendiferous sister! GINTY (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a made up word! BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?! GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the aunt! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! Catch her before she flies away on the-- TRAVERS/GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East Wind! Travers throws his jacket to the ground and begins to cha the hen, tearing through the clean sheets and treading th into the ground. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wash them again my love! Margaret look at the dirty sheets and shrugs. The kids run after their father squealing and giggling as poor little hen runs for its life. Even the dog joins in, Margaret goes to retrieve the discarded jacket and sees a whisky bottle protruding from the inside pocket, she slip back inside - out of sight, out of mind. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go Sergeant Ginty! Fell the beast! Ginty dives on the hapless bird, who pecks her soundly an scarpers. It's chaos. Travers, the girls, the dog and the evasive hen running into each other, falling over each ot cursing and laughing. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Ellie! TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh she's a foul fowl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biddy and Moya sleep but Ginty is awake, the hen snuggled firmly under her arm. She can hear the tense voices of he parents. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --darling, it's just that um-- a LITTLE CONCERNED-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Meg sweet, I had a throat scratch- - MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the bank is getting you down again? Perhaps my sister-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God no! No. I can endure. I will endure. For the girl's sake-- Just, please-- not Ellie. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my dear-- Travers weeps and Ginty closes her eyes, buries her littl face in the hens feathers. GINTY (WHISPERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foul fowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits up in bed - leaning back into the open arms o Mickey Mouse - applying face cream, then hand cream, her is screwed into a twist of unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disney sits on Pamela's bench, deep in contemplation. Piano music tinkles from somewhere in the building and th VOICE-- DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All around the cathedral the saints and apostles look down as she sells her wares Walt is dragged from his thoughts and gets up to follow t sound. DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although you can't see it you know they are smiling Each time someone shows that he CARES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt walks towards the music room, visibly moved by the s a cough rattling in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also in lamplight, Dick Sherman sits at his piano. Bob as on a couch in the corner. Walt pushes the door open, Dick knows he's there but keeps tinkling away. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though her words are simple and few listen, listen, she's calling to YOU--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Feed the birds, tuppence a bag tuppence, tuppence, tuppence a bag." WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll work. Dick nods, still playing. Walt makes his way to the piano sighs, sits next to Dick on the stool. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to say no isn't she? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman's a conundrum. Dick stops playing and flicks to a new page of sheet musi DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man has dreams of walking with GIANTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To carve his niche in the edifice OF TIME (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the mortar of his zeal Has a chance to congeal The cup is dashed from his lips The flame is snuffed aborning He's brought to rack and ruin in HIS PRIME--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt laughs out loud, he sings with Dick reading the lyri from the music sheet. WALT & DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My world was calm, well ordered, EXEMPLARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then came this person, with chaos in her wake And now my life's ambitions go with one fell blow It's quite a bitter pill to take. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspired by someone we know? DICK (FEIGNING INNOCENCE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have to ask Bob. The men smile, bittersweet. DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might surprise us all. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I know it, I know it only too well. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've fought this battle from her side. Pat Powers, he wanted the mouse and I didn't have a bean back then. Dick raises his eyebrows. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was this big terrifying New York producer and I was just a kid from Missouri with a sketch of Mickey but-- it woulda' killed me to give him up. Walt peers down at the sleeping Bob. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest to god killed me. That mouse, he's family. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home. Walt leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits by the pool, arms clasped around her, looking the stars. The pink and green of the hotel shimmers in th water making it look like a chalk painting.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The world is an illusion Ginty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty sits on the front step of the porch, arms clasped around her body, face to the sky. The sounds of the evening closes in - crickets, the last deafening chorus of the birds. Travers walks up the path to their home, trailing his sui jacket over his shoulder, his shirt and tie loosened. His shirtsleeves are marked with sweat. His face is a study o something close to despair. He looks up to see Pamela sitting on the front step and immediately arranges his features into a bright smile of greeting. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh the Countess Mary Sparklestick! Pray tell me, what are you concentrating so hard on? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am laying eggs! TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really!? Fabulous! GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today I am a hen. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed! I can see the feathers sprouting as we speak! Margaret steps out onto the veranda, takes one look at he husband and knows he is drunk. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen Goff, would you lay the table for supper please? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Helen! TRAVERS (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't possibly lay a table; she's busy laying eggs! MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need-- (help.) TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's laying! MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her face contorts in PAIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry! She goes back indoors and slams the door behind her. Gint gets up to go indoors and Travers catches her by the arm. He swallows hard, eyes welling. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent, his voice BREAKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever stop dreaming Ginty my love. You can be anyone you want to be. Anyone. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be like you. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. (HE CHOKES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave yourself always searching for-- something-- He coughs to stop a crying jag and leaves her alone on th porch. Ginty is unnerved by her Travers' demeanor, she creeps ar to the side of the house where she watches her father app in the window of the washroom. She doesn't know what to d he leans his head against the wall and breaks down sobbin   OMITTED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph looks at Pamela in his rear-view, she seems weak, t steely fight flown away on the East wind. Her arms wrappe around her chest, her face turned to the window. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya alright Mrs? Pamela doesn't even hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty stares out of the window, in a daydream, a paintbru in her hand, dripping colour down her arm. She is nudged to the present by her teacher, MRS CORRY. MRS CORRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen Goff? Wake up dear. You want your banner to be ready for the fair don't you? Ginty turns back to her painting - her banner reads: ALLORA FAIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the words Ginty is painting a gorgeous carousel wi stunning horses, one of which is white with roses on its bridal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, Biddy and Ginty walk into the fairground. Tents erected, farmers show off their sheep, children clutch st of cotton candy and a carousel spins with one stunning wh horse amongst the drearier others, roses upon its bridal. BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Brill said Father's presenting the medals. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a flutter of pride) He is indeed! On behalf of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela stares out of the window, not really concentrating what's going on in the room. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers? Again, she doesn't hear. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers? Pamela looks at Don. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just saying that we'd like to play you the song in the bank. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would that be good? Pamela nods, noncommittal. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Dawes Snr) So you have tuppence? May I be permitted to see it? (changing voice to Michael BANKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want it to feed the birds! (back to Dawes Snr) Fiddlesticks boy! Feed the birds and what've you got?

dialogues.speaker: DON/DICK/BOB
dialogues.text: Fat birds! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing more sotto than USUAL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But! If you invest your tuppence wisely in the bank

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Safe and sound-- A small stage and dais stand central of the event over wh a large sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Soon that tuppence safely invested in the bank will compound-- The Allora townsfolk are out in force. Ginty walks with h family. Her father attempting to memorise speech notes as they pass through the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And you'll achieve that sense of CONQUEST--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret nudges him as Randolph Belhatchett and his famil walk past. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clears his throat) Mr Belhatchett. Randolph looks at Travers, then at Travers shaking hands, family nod and move on. Margaret looks upset by this.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As your affluence expands-- Travers buys two immense sticks of fairy floss and hands to Ginty and Biddy. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers, Biddy's stomach-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Gods' sake, Meg, stop whinnying like an old nag will you? Margaret is aghast at being spoken to like that in public she keep her mouth shut. Ginty notices Travers eyes stray towards the refreshments tent. GINTY (PANICKED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father-- will you ride the carousel with me!? But the refreshment tent has Travers in its grip. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet you there in a blink of an eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before. DICK (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hands of the directors who invest as propriety demands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty stands with her family at the carousel, eyeing the refreshment tent. MARGARET (TO GINTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Biddy to get ready for her dance. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your father? Margaret sees the direction of Ginty's gaze. Her face fal but she takes Biddy by the hand and heads for the stage. MARGARET (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Biddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty appears in the tent's entrance. On first glance she sees only an unidentified group of local drinkers. Relief begins to dawn and she turns away. It is then that she hears Travers laugh, and turns back t see the group part, revealing Travers at its centre. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, a published poet-- She takes a deep breath and moves forward, grabs Travers hand. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, come and look. Biddy's dancing. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a moment, my princess. I'm talking. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in Ireland, I miss her green HILLS SO-- GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's-- she really wants you to watch, Dad. You'll miss it. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now Biddy! GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ginty. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty! Shoo! Devastated, Ginty doesn't know what to do, she pulls at h shirt sleeve again. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said don't give up. A waiter approaches and takes her by the arm, leading her away. WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss. It's gentlemen only in this section of the tent. I think you'll be more comfortable at the far end. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright sweetheart? GINTY (TO WAITER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared my father is-- Despairing she looks up and sees her mother, carrying Moy in the entrance. Her mother's face falls and crumples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers steps heavily, one at a time, up the steps onto t dais, and finds his way to the speaker's podium. Margaret and Ginty watch, hearts in mouths, Biddy blissfully unawa TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, distinguished guests, our biggest supporter Mr Randolph Belhatchett and his lovely wife, ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls! Randolph looks at Travers with displeasure and then at on the bank staff. RANDOLPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he speaking for the bank? BANK WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the manager. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honoured to be here on behalf of the Belhatchett Bank of Australia. Shortly, it will be my very pleasant duty to present the awards to our young performers. But before I begin, I'd like to say a very few words to our very youngest citizens about the role of the - er, the Bank in our community. Ginty allows herself to breathe. So far, so good. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's using too many `verys'. He always says `very' too much when HE'S--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't say it. Ginty takes her mother's hand but Marga pushes the hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela turns away from Don and the Shermans and takes her to look at a sketch of Mr Banks, pinned to the wall, he s has a moustache. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Dawes Snr) Very well, my boy, give me the MONEY (AS MICHAEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I won't I want it to feed the birds! (as Dawes Snr) Banks! (AS BANKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Now Micheal... DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you deposit tuppence in a bank account, (MORE) DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon you'll see that it blooms into credit of a generous amount SEMIANNUALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers is now in lip synch with Dick Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And you'll achieve that sense And you'll achieve that sen of stature of stature As your influence expands as your influence expands To the high financial strata To the high financial strata That established credit now That established credit now COMMANDS-- COMMANDS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is up and singing with the boys. They are enjoying themselves so much that they don't notice Pamela's eyes w slightly.

dialogues.speaker: DON/DICK/BOB
dialogues.text: You can purchase first and second TRUST DEEDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the foreclosures! Bonds! Chattels! Dividends! Shares!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bankruptcies! Debtor sales! Opportunities! All manner of private enterprise! Shipyards! The Mercantile! Collieries! Tanneries! Incorporations! Amalgamations! Banks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Dawes Snr) While stand the banks of England. England stands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a smattering of applause, Travers is encouraged, Margaret and Ginty look relieved, even hopeful. But then Travers momentarily looks lost, a slight breeze the speech notes from his hand and they float down in fro of the dais. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhmm. Thank you kindly. Thanking you. Now-- what, what am I doing next? Oh! It's a marvellous idea to encourage children to open accounts. My daughter, the Princess Ginty-- she's-- uh. (looks at Ginty) How old are you? Come up here. Ginty - what? Me? Ginty glances to her mother and then, on trembling legs, makes her way forward and up the stairs onto the dais. Margaret watches, growing uneasy. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty has a bank account-- and that's good. Give her a drink! The audience is shocked. TRAVERS (CONT'D) (MUMBLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean give her a hand. Everyone is beginning to look uncomfortable. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall return in just a moment to present the awards. But right now I must-- relieve myself. Gasps from the audience. Margaret - dying. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us your shoulder, Ginty, will you? I'm busting. There's a good girl. Father and daughter walk towards the edge of the stage, Travers leaning on Ginty's shoulder. The shameful glare o Allora burning into them.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: When fall the banks of England, England falls! Travers somehow loses his footing before reaching the ste and topples off the stage. There's an audible, horrible s as he lands in an undignified pile. But, despite his ugly injury, Travers cannot stop laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are laughing, congratulating one another. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Walt's gonna like it? Pamela takes a last look at the Mr Banks picture and spin around viciously. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you have to make him so cruel? The boys jubilance is halted immediately. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was not a monster! DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we talking about? I'm confused. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all have children yes? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. DICK BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Yes.  PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do those children write you letters, make drawings for you? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine like to make folded paper-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) And would you tear up those gifts? In front of them?! Silence. They know where this is going. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dreadful thing to do! I don't understand! Why must father tear up the advertisement his children have written and throw it in the fireplace!? Why won't he mend their kite? Why have you made him so unspeakably awful? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all the world to see, in glorious technicolor? You claim to make them live-- if that happens can't he? Can't they at least live well? Pamela chokes back a sudden rush of distress. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't bear it. (SOFTLY) PLEASE DON'T--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are shocked at the level of upset. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't-- I'll feel like I let him down again-- She leaves the room, head hung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers is in bed, his leg elevated and set with plaster. is shaking badly with DT's, his mood is poisonous. Ginty sits on the edge of the bed as the DOCTOR packs up bag. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose there's any more you can give me for the pain? The doctor shakes his head at Travers wanton greed for mo DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving the room) When will enough be enough Travers? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've brought you something father. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a darling Ginty my old pal! Help father out won't you? Ginty is wary. TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my washroom-- there's a bottle of medicine that father needs-- GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother took it away. Travers slams his fist on the bed, scaring Ginty. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godammit! Nervous, hopeful, Ginty withdraws a folded sheet of paper from her pocket. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote a poem for you. It - it won first prize, at school. Travers takes the page, tries to hold it steady in his shaking hand. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to read it to you? The agony as Ginty watches the shaking hand. Finally, the humiliation is too much for Travers. He scans the page rapidly and lowers his hand. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hardly Yeats, is it? Ginty is devastated. But more than this there's a hardeni in her small face, a sense of disillusionment that so far she's held in check. Here are the first signs of the Pame to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela rushes from the rehearsal room, down the corridor, face twisted, desperately trying to maintain composure. D rushes out after her. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers! He stops, recognizing she doesn't need to be followed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty rummages through kitchen cabinets, drawers, the tra but doesn't find what she's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela rushes past Minnie Mouse and Daisy Duck, through t lot, past Ralph - who's taking his lunch at the cafeteria and towards a patch of green, a communal lawn at the back a soundstage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty fights the smell of the warm rubbish in the midday as she ransacks the outdoor trash cans, finally finding w it is she's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela flops down onto the ground, digging her fingers in the dirt and lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty creeps into her father's room, he sleeps fitfully, presses the half-full bottle into his hand. Covering both hand and bottle with his bed covers before leaving the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela picks a daisy, finds a stray twig and arranges the the grass. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs? Pamela looks up, her eyes are red rimmed but she's not crying. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh, brought you a tea. He hands her the tea in a takeaway cup. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's blasphemy to drink tea from a paper cup. Ralph, shifts nervously from foot to foot. He's not quite sure what to say to her or why he brought the tea. Pamela puts the tea down and continues to fiddle with bit and pieces of twig and bloom that she's plucking from the area around her. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay Ma'am? Would you like me to drive you home? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the way to England? Yes, please. Ralph lowers himself onto his haunches. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got family back there Mrs? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an impertinent man you know? You ask an awful lot of questions that have no relevance to you being able to carry out your duties. RALPH (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! I do, do that. Yes! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have no barometer. Ralph is confused. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us say that I haven't family who'd notice whether I was halfway across the world or sitting in my living room. She pulls a thread from the hem of her skirt, ties two tw together. RALPH MA'AM; I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph sees that she has a little collection of things, he looks around for some more. Pamela takes a stick and digs small line through the grass then hands it to him. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a little furrow, there. Ralph dutifully does as he's told, looking over his shoul for fear of being caught digging holes in Disney soil. Ralph pokes the ground, thinking. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta kid. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, most people do. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane-- she's got all kinds of troubles. Pamela raises an eyebrow. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handicapped you know? Myelitis--  transverse. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in a wheelchair see? That's why I concern myself with the weather-- sunny day she can sit out in the garden. Rainy day I have to leave her cooped up inside. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worry `bout the future, but then I stop cuz you can't do that. Only today. Pamela takes the plastic lid off the paper cup and pokes holes in it. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look. She takes the lid, twigs now sticking out of the poked ho and places it in the centre of what we now see is one of Pamela's tiny parks, she gently rest a leaf on the twig struts forming a roof. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a band stand. She takes the cup of tea and gently pours the steaming li into Ralph's trench, which runs all the way around the pa RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A river! PAMELA (CORRECTING HIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lake. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lake. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I wish I could take her there! He points at the miniature park. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't that be nice? INT. GINTY BIDDY & MOYA'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Ginty, Biddy and Moya sleep soundly, Ginty clutching the to her chest. The door creeps open and Margaret stands in the shadows looking at her children, tears stream down her face but s seems calm, something has crossed over in her eyes. There just nothing there-- MARGARET (WHISPERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you gave it to him. (squeezing Ginty's hand) All the hope is in the bottom of that bottle, Helen. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother? MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take care of the children. Ginty is groggy, she doesn't understand. MARGARET (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch over them. Ginty sits up. MARGARET (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you love your father more. But one day you'll understand. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Margaret leaves the room and Ginty is straight out of bed following her. Behind, in the room, Moya has awoken and i crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty runs out onto the porch where she sees her mother i her white nightdress striding purposefully through the ga like some ethereal ghost. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! She runs out into the yard but stops as she hears Biddy.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Ginty! Ginty turns back to the house and then back towards her mother but Margaret has disappeared into the darkness. GINTY (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! Mother! The baby is screaming now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GINTY BIDDY & MOYA'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Ginty wrenches the eiderdown off the bed and wraps Biddy it, she scoops Moya up from the crib. BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's ma? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there were three little girls alone in a house. They were frightened of the big wide world just outside the door. She takes them through the hallway, stopping momentarily outside the door to her fathers bedroom. It is slightly a and he looks incredibly frail and delirious. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were so afraid. She moves forward, her eyes flit to the front door, expec her mother to be standing there any minute but there is nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mud-stained hem of Margaret's nightdress sweeps along ground, as her feet move towards, and then into, the wate the creek. One step, two, three, the water coming up over ankles, soaking the nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: GINTY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the stars were guarding them, they glittered as they spoke "We shall send a guide to show them the way to the magical ladder which will bring them all the way up to SEE US"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biddy and Moya are calming as Ginty places the girls in f of the fireplace. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who do you think those sparkling messengers sent? Who was it that came flying through the starry, starry sky to carry us up to see them? Ginty wraps Moya in a blanket and puts her in Biddy's arm BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty begins to untie Albert from the fence still speakin the girls through the window. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their old Uncle Albert of course! (beat, to Biddy) Stay right here, be good-- Ginty climbs atop the horse. BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to the sky? GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to find the end of the story so I can bring it back for you! BIDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty rides fast, desperately searching the darkness for mother and turning back frequently to check that the lamp still burns on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is up to her neck in the freezing water of the creek. Shivering cold. She wills herself forward into the water. She wants to sink down and simply float away. From behind her comes the clip clopping of hooves. Margar turns her head and there, atop the horse, is Ginty. Margaret begins to weep. Ginty jumps down from the horse and rushes to her mother, wading into the water to grab hold of her. Ginty bobs up and down in front of her mother in the deep water. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes a person we love, through no fault of his own, can't see past the end of his nose. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to go home, ma. She reaches out her hand--  OMITTED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela looks through a stack of books intently, jotting something down on a piece Beverly Hills Hotel stationery every now and then. Presently, the phone rings. Pamela almost jumps out of he skin. She rushes to grab it. PAMELA (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers! Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt sits at his desk, flicking through cartoon drawings penguins. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs into phone) Pam! INTERCUT BETWEEN PHONE CALLS AS NECESSARY. PAMELA (DISAPPOINTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Disney. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Callin' to check up on you. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a doctor? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check ups are for medical practitioners no? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, are you always so battle ready? P.L. Travers in her breast plate and chain mail, sword up in the air and off with your head! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you Mister Disney? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I beg of you, please please call me Walt. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt-- er. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard things didn't go so well today. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went as well as they've gone every other day that I've been here. I don't recall `special' phone calls from you on any of those other evenings. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this all about Pam? Really? Silence. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wondering what I have to do to make you happy. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you wondering that too? Silence. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has an idea) You know, you've never been to Disneyland! It's the happiest place on Earth! (shouting away from the PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommie! Cancel my morning tomorrow. I'm taking a ride with my favorite author! (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any excuse. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot tell you how uninterested, no, positively sickened I am at the thought of going to see your dollar printing machine Mr-- Walter. She notices Mickey's innocent eyes staring at her and gen turns his face away. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on! When does anybody get to go to Disneyland with Walt Disney himself?! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointments are to the soul what the thunderstorm is to the air. Walt slams the phone down. Pamela stares at it in shock! PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? He hung up! I'm! I! I can't believe he hung up! Walt leans back in his chair and grins, Tommie enters. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a violent man Tommie but if Mrs P.L. Travers were to get hit by a large truck I-- (he doesn't allow himself TO FINISH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, Bob and Don are drained. They stare at each other i silence. Just the look tells us how much this all means t them. It's desperate. Walt flings the door to the room op WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay boys. We gotta fix this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty sits beside her father, he is restless and sweating his sleep as she wipes his face with a damp sponge. The sound of a buggy pulling up outside breaks the silenc

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh my! And then a new voice, clear as a crystal bell.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELLIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Margaret, my poor child. I simply had to come. We must fix this. Travers eyes spring wide open in horror. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parrot headed umbrella hangs from the back of a chair. An enormous carpetbag - similar to the one Pamela carries plonked on the living room table and there beside it, upright, imposing and matronly is AUNT ELLIE herself. Hai scraped back, hands neatly perched inside her apron pocke a very different version but Mary Poppins all the same. Ginty looks on in awed silence as Ellie begins to remove endless supply of belongings from her bag. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I've brought every new fangled treatment available in Sydney. Biddy is open mouthed. ELLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your mouth please Biddy, we are not a codfish. (to both girls) I spy a multitude of jobs to be done! MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been so worried-- I've-- ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do stop babbling nonsense! I'm here now and I shall fix everything. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feverfew and camomile to lower his body temperature. Garlic, sorrel, sage. Deadly nightshade. And if those don't work-- well I shouldn't like to say. Young Pamela and Biddy look on in a kind of bewildered tr as item after item emerges from the carpetbag. ELLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --tincture of horseradish-- LAUDANUM--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ginty and Biddy) (MORE) ELLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had made it quite clear you were to begin helping. Ellie claps her hands together. ELLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spit spot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph drives along solemnly. Pamela looks out of the wind confused. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we--? This isn't the way. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change of venue this morning apparently. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing where she's BEING TAKEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about our-- tea party? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't know what you're-- RALPH (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, the little park. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little park? I haven't a clue what you're talking about. RALPH BUT-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concentrate on the road. Always chitter chattering!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph drives Pamela up to the entrance to the park. Two security guards stop the car briefly and then the gates p open to reveal Walt Disney waiting for Pamela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph is goggle-eyed at seeing Walt. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Isn't that nice? Holy mackerel! Wowzers. Never met him myself but there he is! Right there. Real. Living, breathing. Oh boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph jump out of the car to let his passenger out but Di is there first. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Magic Kingdom! Pamela steps out of the car and her eyes nearly pop out o her head with brightness of the place, unbelievable colou and excitement. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all like this? Pamela pops a headache pill. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup! Isn't it wonderful? Ralph hovers at the car, filling his eyeballs with as muc Walt Disney as he can get before he has to drive away. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always get everything you want Walter? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the exception to the rights to my books of course! WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War ain't over yet Pam! Walt takes Pamela by the arm and leads her through the ga and a murmur goes through the crowds as they gawp. A YOUN WOMAN breaks free and rushes up to Walt. YOUNG WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much! Can I--? She proffers a pen and paper but Walt is prepared, he tak signed postcard with his face on it from his top pocket a hands it to the woman. PAMELA (DISGUSTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-signed? WALT (TO WOMAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get hers too. (gesturing to Pamela) This woman's a bona fide genius! The woman looks expectantly at Pamela who just snorts. sh realizes she's getting nothing and, clutching her preciou postcard to her chest, melts back into the crowd who part like the red sea for Walt and his guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt and Pamela make their way down Main Street. Walt sto anyone from getting too close by immediately handing out postcards to anyone who gets near. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Adventureland there is a tree-- this is a fun fact. A titbit. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tidbit. WALT (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has three million leaves, four million flowers. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they said only God could make a tree! Pamela rolls her eyes. There is a protracted silence as they walk, both encompas by their own thoughts. The sunshine, the joyful crowds ju background colour. They pass by a store front and Walt glances up at the win It reads: Elias Disney Contractor Est. 1895. Pamela notic the look but doesn't say anything. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she come from? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know who. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flew in through the window one day. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window huh? Pamela nods curtly. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that easy isn't it Mrs Travers? He sees right through her. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't wanna be here so I'm gonna take you to one ride-- my favourite amusement and then I'll set you free. Way ahead of them the carousel spins in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carousel slows to a halt and a herd of excited childr climb down from the horses and disappear into the park. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers, I would be honoured if you would ride Jingles. She's Mrs Disney's favourite horse. He escorts Pamela to a beautiful white horse, roses on it bridal. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. I'm happy to watch. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No greater joy than that seen through the eyes of a child. Pamela looks at the children climbing onto the carousel. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a child in us all. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe in you Mister Disney, but certainly not I. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on the horse Pamela! Pamela sighs and allows Walt to help her onto the horse. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we first met, you said to me `they're family.' PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said what? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins, the Banks's, they're family. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys have had an idea for your Mister Banks. I think it'll make you happy. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought me all the way out here to tell me that? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I brought you all the way out here for monetary gain. Had a wager with the boys that I couldn't get you on a ride. I win! He clambers onto his own horse, gestures to the ride controller and off they go! Pamela gently bobs up and down, Walt waves to her and she sees the unbridled thrill from the child in Mister Disney spilling out. The tiniest, tiniest of smiles threatens to surface on her lips as he points a finger in the air as i shooting for the stars. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers has a violent coughing fit, he looks to his hand, disturbed to see blood there. He grimaces at Ellie who ha her back to him as she folds clothes, a look of deep satisfaction on her face. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well begun, is half done! His face softens as his hazy gaze falls upon Ginty, outsi the window, sweeping. Their eyes meet for a brief moment, unspoken understanding of what is to come, before his clo with tiredness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the tables have been pushed to the walls, Don is just pushing the last one away as Pamela comes in, followed by Dolly with the tray carrying Pamela's tea. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning Mrs Travers! She looks at the new arrangement of the room. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What horrors have you in store for my beautiful characters today, hm? Bob clenches a fist but Dick gives him a look that says: calm. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mrs Travers you sit here. He ushers her to a chair facing the centre of the room. H hands pages to Bob and pages to Dolly. Don and Dolly drop their knees so that they are half the height of Bob. Pamela raises an eyebrow. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought about what you said Mrs Travers and Mr Banks isn't cruel. He isn't. We've got a new ending for the film. Oh god, I hope you like it. Bob pulls a kite out from behind his back. DON (CONT'D) (AS MICHAEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael says, "He mended it! It's wonderful!" DOLLY (AS JANE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However did you manage it? PAMELA (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mended it? Dick strikes a chord on the piano. DICK (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With tuppence for paper and strings You can have your own set of wings With your feet on the ground You're a bird in flight with your fist holding tight To the string of your kite Oh oh oh oh Bob takes the hands of Don and Dolly and he dances around with them (awkwardly as they are still on their knees and has a limp.) Pamela's eyes on the fixed kite. DICK & BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go fly a kite Up to the highest height Let's go fly a kite and send it SOARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up through the atmosphere Up where the air is clear Oh let's go fly a kite Don notices Pamela's foot tapping, he stands up. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then Mrs Banks goes to fetch her suffragettes ribbon. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Mrs Banks) "A proper kite needs a proper tail don't you think?!" Don drops to his knees again.

dialogues.speaker: BOB/DICK/DON/DOLLY
dialogues.text: Let's go fly a kite Up to the highest height Is Pamela humming too?!

dialogues.speaker: BOB/DICK/DON/DOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go fly a kite and send it SOARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don bows to Pamela puts his hand out to her and to his surprise, she accepts and they begin to waltz. Pamela is surprisingly elegant and accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: BOB/DICK/DON/DOLLY/PAMELA
dialogues.text: Up through the atmosphere Up where the air is clear Oh let's go fly a kite Everybody is up and dancing, it's like something out of a Disney movie! DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you send it flying up there All at once you're lighter than air Dolly breaks away and rushes from the room. DICK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can dance on the breeze over houses and trees--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly pants her way to the top of the stairs, and sees Wa just about to enter his office. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Disney! Walt! Walt spins around. DOLLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt. It's just she-- she's dancing! Mrs Travers. She's dancing with Don! He cracks a great big smile.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With your fist holding tight To the string of your kite

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before.

dialogues.speaker: BOB/DICK/DON/PAMELA
dialogues.text: Oh Oh Oh Oh Let's go fly a kite Up to the highest height Let's go fly a kite and send it SOARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up through the atmosphere Up where the air is clear Oh let's go fly a kite! They all collapse in a heap, exhausted and thrilled. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! He fixes the kite! Oh, I love it! Dick punches the air. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though proper English would be `Let us go and fly a kite.' Bob glares at her. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I might be willing to overlook that. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we get that on tape? Everybody sighs with relief and Pamela looks to the caricature of Mr Banks with deep warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty sits with her father, he's a shadow of his former s extremely ill. The shaking has stopped, his lips are parc and blueish. TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you-- all ship shape. Travers reaches up a shaking hand and musses up Ginty's perfectly plaited hair. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I re-wrote the poem father. Travers doesn't respond. Ginty reaches into her pocket, t out tuppence. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aunt gave me tuppence. She shows it to him in her open palm. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I buy you something father? TRAVERS (BARELY AUDIBLE) PEARS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits bolt upright in bed, panicked. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty skips off the porch, clutching her tuppence. Chatte to herself about pears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo crests the top of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph admires the view as he always does. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know you're quite right? It is beautiful. Exquisite. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela leans on the piano peering at her script. The boys dotted about the room; all are mid-work. DON (TO PAMELA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Jolly Holiday's in? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you wish. Pamela is genuinely curious. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, how in the world does Mister Disney propose to train penguins to dance?! BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard about his implausibly leaved trees so I assume he does have some insane penguin wrangling scheme but it does seem rather far fetched. Can you train penguins? DON (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't think you can train an ACTUAL-- DICK (OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're animated. Pamela is confounded. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cartoons. He draws a little squiggle in the air to illustrate his point. DON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick. Pamela's face turns beetroot red, she pushes herself away from the table and storms out of the room, slamming the d behind her. DON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Are we getting real penguins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela comes storming into the offices suite. Dolly smile from her desk. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon Mrs Travers! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Mister Disney? DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd like to take a seat-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would not like to take a seat thank you. I would like to-- She heads for Disney's office and Dolly is up and running after her down the corridor. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers, please! Pamela blows past Tommie's desk. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela pushes open Walt's doors, catching him in the mids signing a stack of postcards of his grinning face, an unl cigarette in his pen hand. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, I'm so sorry. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry Tommie, please close the door. Disney gestures to his cigarette. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never let anybody see me smoking. I'd hate to encourage bad habits. Please, sit down. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall not sit in the seat of a trickster! A fraudster! A sneak! WALT PAMELA-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: MRS TRAVERS. PLEASE
dialogues.text: WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers, what in the world has upset you so? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penguins! Walt is confused. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penguins have very much upset me Mister Disney! Animated, dancing penguins! Now, you have seduced me with the music Mr Disney, yes you have. Those Sherman boys have quite turned my head but I shall not be moved on the matter of cartoons. Not one inch sir! WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sequence-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised me. You promised me that this film would not be an animation! WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it isn't! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they're real penguins? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No they're animated. PAMELA (SUDDEN REALIZATION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (to herself, smiling RUEFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You foolish old woman. Pamela reaches into her purse and pulls out the assignmen rights papers and leaves them on the table. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day Mister Disney. She turns on her heel and leaves. Disney stares at the pa aghast. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam! Pamela! Mrs Travers! Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela flies past Dolly's desk. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call my driver and have him pick me up. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am, when? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela flees to her bench, wrapping her arms around herse Disney comes after her. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Mrs Travers-- You must listen. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't make promises you can't keep, especially to children, they hold on to them you see? And those promises they just sit there inside of them, like little doses of poison, all those broken promises, eating away forever. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela? I don't understand why this is so hard for you. Please, make me UNDERSTAND-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The books weren't written for the children. They were written for the promise breakers. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The promise breakers? Mrs Travers I- -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's gone, face to the sky, eyes closed, breathing. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers? Ralph pulls up and gets out of the car. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah! Mister Disney! WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! I'm such a huge fan. It's such an honour to-- He suddenly sees that Pamela is more deeply entrenched in herself than usual and his priority becomes her. RALPH (CONT'D) (TO WALT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Ralph moves past Walt and gently taps Pamela on the shoul she opens her eyes, relieved to see him. RALPH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to go Mrs? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. WALT PAMELA-- PAMELA (TEARING UP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry Mister Disney. To have put everyone to so much trouble. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must reconsider. You must. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply can't give her up. Not yet. Perhaps not ever. I don't know WHY DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know why! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, he's-- DISNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just-- Goodbye Mr Disney. She goes to get in the car and Disney puts a hand to stop but Ralph blocks it. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady's ready to go now sir. Walt steps away and Ralph closes the door to the car. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's? Walt watches the car disappear, wracked with frustration confusion. He takes a seat on Pamela's bench and wraps hi arms around himself and looks to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph climbs out of the limo and opens the back door for Pamela. He gestures for a valet to come and take her bags opens the trunk of the car. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure driving you Mrs. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one likes a fibber. RALPH (CHUCKLES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really have enjoyed it. Didn't know who you were at first and then guess what? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found out? RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was telling my daughter all about my day and how I was driving this nice writer lady, Mrs Travers for Mr Disney and-- PAMELA AND-- RALPH AND--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he leans into the PASSENGER WINDOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she makes me go to her bedroom and get this! (he pulls out a Mary POPPINS BOOK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't stop reading it. I'm very slow mind you. Pamela smiles. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to sign it? RALPH (DELIGHTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you?! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be honoured. Ralph hands her his pen and she begins to write. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughters name? RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Like the girl in the book. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading as she writes) To Jane and her dearest father-- (she looks at him) I've just this instant realized I don't know your name. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph. She shakes his hand. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only American I have ever liked, Ralph. Ralph is chuffed to bits. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask why? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Now take this-- She hands him the piece of Beverly Hills Hotel stationery with her notes on. RALPH (READING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert Einstein, Van Gogh, Roosevelt, Frida Kahlo-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all had difficulties. Jane can do anything that anyone else can do, do you understand? Ralph looks at her in awe. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the bottom. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt Disney! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deficiencies in concentration and hyperactive behavior. Explains everything! Pamela turns to leave. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mrs. Pamela doesn't look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommie and Dolly silence their gossiping as a tired and broken Walt Disney appears in front of them. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone? Tommie looks down at her paperwork and nods at Walt apologetically. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight left 10 minutes ago. Tommie hands him the itinerary, he glares at it. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expecting to read her NAME) PAMELA TRA-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goff? Who's Helen Goff? TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her. That's her real name. Walt is confused. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuh, didn't you know? She's all hoity toity. British this and British that and she's really an Aussie called Helen Goff. Stuck up-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who's Travers? Tommie and Dolly look at each other and shrug. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles to himself) I've been talking to the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty skips up the path, clutching a brown paper bag. She ruffles Andrew's fur before entering the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty senses something wrong, she hears hushed, urgent an emotional voices in the hall. She pokes her head into the hallway. There, huddled together, whispering are her moth the doctor and Aunt Ellie. Ellie is holding a pile of blood stained sheets. Ginty stands frozen, trying to still the panicked beating her heart. Margaret spies Ginty and moves towards her as if in slo-m There are flecks of blood on her dress. She is ashen, shattered. She comes down to Ginty's level. MARGARET DADDY--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty cannot react. Margaret sweeps her into her arms and Ginty drops the bro paper bag; it tears and scatters pears all over the floor Ginty's eyes fix on Aunt Ellie's umbrella on the back of chair, drawn into its beady black eyes. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see my father. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you mustn't. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him! Suddenly she turns into a wildcat - lashing, thrashing, biting, screaming. Nothing will stop her seeing Travers. AUNT ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her go Margaret. Margaret is forced to let go and Ginty runs for her fathe bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginty stands in the bedroom, a long way from the bed. She stands there, it seems, for an eternity. Then, finally, s by step she draws closer. The empty bottle on the floor. sheets twisted, still wet with sweat, flecked and spotted with blood. The front of her father's nightdress is also bloodstained. Ginty's eyes reach his face. Travers lies, open, mouth open, teeth slightly red-stained, neither peaceful nor distressed. Just-- nothing. GINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dropped the pears. She perches on the edge of the bed and takes his hand. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry daddy. Ellie appears in the doorway, Ginty addresses her without turning around. GINTY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised you would fix everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black London Taxi pulls up outside the house. Pamela cl out of the car, struggling to pull her huge Mickey Mouse too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela moves through the vestibule, lugging her suitcase. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits in a chair in the living room watching in darkness. She gently closes her eyes, ringed with sadness a lifetime's despair. There's a knock at the door and she jolts awake, she does know how long she's been asleep but it's black outside. S gets up and rushes to the door as quickly as her feet wil take her. She swings it open. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear god! Standing on the doorstep is Walt Disney. Pamela is, quite literally, speechless. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was one heck of a job getting a seat on the very next flight, let me tell you. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, you always get what you want eventually. Isn't that right Walter? He looks down at her hand clenched into a fist and shakin WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you show me how to make one of those nice English pots of tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits at the table, as Disney carries in a tray wit teapot, a milk jug, a sugar bowl and two cups. These he places on the table and proceeds to pour tea. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk. The milk goes in first. He attends to it. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whiskey. I'll have whiskey in mine. Disney follows her gesture to the whiskey decanter. She t it from him and pours a generous slug into her teacup. WALT (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well, when in Rome! He pours a slug into his tea too. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come to change my mind. To beat me into submission. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've come because you misjudge me. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I misjudge you? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look at me and you see some kind of Hollywood King Midas. (MORE) WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I've built an empire and that I want to use your Mary Poppins as just another brick in my kingdom. You think I see her with a carpetbag full of greenbacks. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't you? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was all it was would I have pursued an cranky, stubborn dame like you for twenty years? I'd've have saved myself an ulcer! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you expected me to disappoint you and so you made sure I did. You see, I think life disappoints you, Mrs Travers. I think it's done that a lot. Maybe Mary Poppins is the only person in your life who hasn't. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins isn't real. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, that's not true. She's real as can be to my daughter's and to thousands of other children-- adults too. She's been there as a nighttime comfort to a heck of a lot of people. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Where is she when I need her? Hm? I open the door to Mary Poppins and who should be standing there but Walt Disney! He laughs. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers, I am so sorry. I hoped this would be a magical experience for you, for all of us. But I let you down-- and in doing so, I've broken a twenty year old promise to my girls. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wracking my brains, trying to figure out why this has been so hard for you and I-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I have my own Mr Banks. Mine had a moustache. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Not true then that Disney created man in his own image? WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
