dialogues.text: But it is true that you created yourself in someone else's yes? She doesn't answer. Walt takes mouthful of laced tea and coughs a little. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever been to Kansas City, Mrs Travers? Do you know Missouri at all? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say I do and as I have no plans to ever set foot on American soil again I'm afraid I never will. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mighty cold there in the winters. Bitter. Walt stops talking, catches himself, looks away and then gives in. His enthusiasm completely disappears and he's suddenly as ragged and as weary as Pamela. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it pours out) My dad, Elias Disney, he owned a newspaper delivery route there. Thousand papers. Twice daily. Morning and evening edition. Elias, he was a tough businessman. A save- a-penny anywhere you can type of fella so he wouldn't employ any delivery boys, he just used me and my big brother Roy. I was eight then-- eight years old. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, those winters were harsh and old Elias didn't believe in new shoes until the old ones were worn right through so-- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, Mrs Travers, the snow would be up to here-- He gestures to his knees. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd push through it like wading through molasses. (MORE) WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the cold and the wet would be seeping through the shoes and the skin would be raw and peeling from our faces-- and sometimes I'd find myself sunk down in the snow, waking up, cuz I must've passed out for a moment-- I dunno. Then school, too cold to figure out an equation. And back into the snow so by the time we got home it'd be just getting dark, and every part of you would sting like crazy as it slowly came back to life in the warmth. My mother would feed us dinner and then it'd be time to go out again for the evening edition. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best be quick Walt, best be quick or poppa's gonna show you the buckle end again boy. Walt smiles at Pamela, sips his tea. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I don't tell you all this to make you sad Mrs Travers, I don't. I love my life - it's a miracle. And I loved my daddy, boy I loved him. But, there isn't a day goes by where I don't think of that little boy in the snow and old Elias with his fist and strap and I'm just so tired-- I'm tired of remembering it that way. Aren't you tired Mrs Travers? We all have our tales but don't you want to find a way to finish the story? Let it all go and have a life that isn't dictated by a past? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the children she comes to save. It's their father. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your father--? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travers Goff. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you think you know about me Walter-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must've loved and admired him a lot to take his name-- PAMELA I-- WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Travers. It's all about him isn't it? All of this. Everything. Pamela looks at her hands, they're shaking. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgiveness. It's what I learned from your books. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to forgive my father. He was a wonderful man. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you need to forgive Helen Goff. Life is a harsh sentence to lay down for yourself. Pamela looks down at the table top. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her to me, Mrs Travers. Trust me with your precious Mary Poppins. I won't disappoint you. I swear that every time a person goes into a movie house - from Leicester to St Louis, they will see George Banks being saved. They will love him and his kids, they will weep for his cares, and wring their hands when he loses his job. And when he flies that kite, oh! They will rejoice, they will sing. In every movie house, all over the world, in the eyes and the hearts of my kids, and other kids and their mothers and fathers for generations to come, George Banks will be honoured. George Banks will be redeemed. George Banks and all he stands for will be saved. Maybe not in life, but in imagination. Because that's what we storytellers do. We restore order with imagination. We instill hope again and again and again. Trust me, Mrs Travers. Let me prove it to you. I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela is alone. The unsigned rights papers in front of h on the table. She looks at Mickey who occupies the chair opposite her, her face softens under his gaze. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disney employees pass by a giant movie poster which reads MARY POPPINS - OPENING SOON! Walt exits the building. He' but a few steps out of the door when Tommie appears behin him. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt. She hands him a sheet of paper. TOMMIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invitation list for the premiere. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that everyone? TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone. She looks at Walt questioningly. WALT (SIGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll premiere in London as well. It'll be more convenient for her. Tommie holds his look. WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be cameras, press, interviews-- I have to protect the picture. TOMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Walt walks away, he's lost a bit of steam. Tommy watches go.   OMITTED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela taps away on her typewriter with gusto. She pings return and breathes, satisfied. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should say so too. The doorbell sounds, voices. Pamela begins to tap again.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers! Pamela tuts, tries to carry on with her work.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers! Pamela rises from her chair, smoothes down her skirt. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For goodness sake! She rises from her chair, smoothes down her skirt and mak her way to the front door. PAMELA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't screech like an alleycat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela and Diarmuid sit together. Pamela is quite changed she looks younger, radiant, worry free. DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so pleased to hear that Mrs Travers. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should think you'll have a draft very soon. (CALLING OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polly! Where's that tea? (TO DIARMUID)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming along marvelously! Polly kicks the door open with her foot and plonks the te down in front of Pamela and Diarmuid. She sneezes twice, doesn't bother to pour and turns to leave. PAMELA (CONT'D) (TO POLLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you pour please? POLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're perfectly capable of doing it yourself. Polly leaves, Pamela rolls her eyes. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quite the worst maid I've ever had! DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do you keep her? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know-- she reminds me of me. Diarmuid laughs. DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a title? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins in the Kitchen. DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. Should we start talking about the film rights? Pamela narrows her eyes at him. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEVER again. DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, tell me, Have you got your tiara for the premiere? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not going. DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood premieres are not for old trout like me. Anyway, it's not CONVENIENT-- DIARMUID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't invited you, has he? Pamela doesn't reply. DIARMUID (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins wouldn't stand for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela is hot and bothered trying to wrestle her cabin baggage into an overhead locker. The same flight attendan from the top of the film appears. FLIGHT ATTENDANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly capable thank you. The flight attendant recognizes her with something akin t horror. FLIGHT ATTENDANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself-- ma'am. PAMELA (CHEERY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon and welcome aboard this flight to Los Angeles. Just a few announcements before we begin our taxi for takeoff-- Pamela takes the seat next to the window, she looks out a the tarmac. She closes her eyes, takes a deep breath, opens her eyes again and tucks her feet tidily together. She folds her h neatly into her lap and looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt enters the outer office walking briskly towards his office. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Dolly. Dolly opens her mouth to speak but he's already past and APPROACHING-- TOMMIE'S DESK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommie sits, arms crossed and stares, half bemused at Wal WALT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Tommie nods toward his office. Pamela is sitting in a cha back to them. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt semi-recovers as quickly as possible and enters his office. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Travers! How wonderful to see you. What brings you to-- PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for my premiere. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!   PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't receive my invitation, but I just assumed the American postal service had fallen down on the job as per usual. She smiles sweetly. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a-- uh, replacement sent to your hotel right away. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind, Mr Disney. I knew you wouldn't have forgotten me. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, how could I? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How indeed? You did, after all, assure me that I wouldn't be disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The porter lets Pamela into her room, and doesn't even bo hovering for a tip. Pamela turns and it's like deju vu - the flowers, the chocolates, the champagne, a VIP invitation to the premie of Walt Disney's Mary Poppins. And, of course, the ubiqui stuffed Mickey Mouse. PAMELA (TO MICKEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I left you in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela looks wonderful in a long white gown with turquois silk gloves to her elbows and matching wrap falling from shoulders. PAMELA (TO DOORMAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you call me a taxi please? DOORMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. The doorman goes to find her a cab and in his absence a l pulls up to the kerb. Pamela doesn't dare get her hopes u but the door swings open and there he is, her favorite pe in America. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a feeling a certain friend of mine might be needing me tonight. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph! She rushes to him and they give each other a friendly hug RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a million bucks! Let's get you to the ball. He opens the back door for her and she climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's spectacular! Disney's biggest Hollywood opening. Bul flash continuously as limo after limo pulls up at the red carpet. Ushers are dressed as English bobbies. Reporters stand on podiums in colourful suits, Penguins dance their hearts out in front of the theater. Pearly Kings and Quee play for the onlookers. Crowds and crowds of fans scream every time a bulb flashes, waving their autograph books a posters in the air. Every Disney character imaginable bou up and down the lines of well-wishers, hugging them, danc for them, signing their booklets. Hollywood Blvd is completely shut down and the atmosphere is like the happi party you could ever go to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph takes the car slowly through the crowds. Onlookers press their faces against the windows trying to make out is inside. Pamela is nervous, everyone else has someone w them but Pamela must brave the crowd alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo stops at the edge of the carpet and Ralph jumps He rushes round to Pamela's side and helps her from the c Immediately a round of flashes go off and Pamela puts her up to shield her eyes. It's too much. RALPH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in her ear) This is your night. None of this would be possible without you. She brings her arm down, straightens her dress and breaks into a smile, making her way down the carpet to frantic whispers amongst the press and autograph hunters of: "Who that?" "Is that anyone?" Pamela spots Walt, Dick Van Dyke Julie Andrews being interviewed together up ahead. Mickey Mouse bounces down the carpet and slows-- he and Pamela lock eyes for a brief moment. He holds out his glo hand, she takes it and together they watch as a huge toy train chugs to a halt on the blvd and hundreds upon hundr of coloured balloons fly out of it's roof and into the ai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela moves through the spangling, glittering, perfect toothed Hollywood crowd and no-one pays any attention to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auditorium is jam packed. Pamela is seated in front o Walt Disney. Don, the Shermans and their families are in same row as her - Bob Sherman next to her. The lights beg to dim. The overture begins-- We stay close on Pamela as the sounds of the overture fad and the melody of a single tin whistle playing one of Tra old melody's rings in her ears. We hear snippets of the film in the background but we rem with Pamela. She looks around at the faces in the audience - laughing, humming, sad, happy, joyous. Intercut with images from Pamela's childhood and the voic of Bert and Jane - Ellie's parrot head umbrella-- BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, begging your pardon, but the one my heart goes out to is your father. The carousel horses at the Allora fair-- BERT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is in that cold, heartless bank day after day, hemmed in by mounds of cold, heartless money. The tuppence and rolling pears-- BERT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to see any living thing caged up. Uncle Albert with Ginty on his back, carrying her river soaked mother back to the house-- JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father in a cage? Ginty pressing the final bottle into her father's hand-- BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They makes cages in all sizes and shapes, you know. The image of the dead Travers in his bloodstained bed-- BERT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank-shaped some of 'em, carpets and all. DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children in the audience, their little faces tilted upwar Rapt. MICHEAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't ever leave us will you? JANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever would we do without you? MARY POPPINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall stay until the wind changes. And then an image from the film: George Banks walks away from us down the misty tree-lined London street, on his way to be fired from the bank. Walt Disney watches with quiet satisfaction. Pamela however has tears coursing down her face. Her shoulders heave as she tries desperately not to sob out l but people are noticing, looking at her. Disney leans forward, placing a hand on her shoulder. She reaches up and grips it tightly, unable to speak. WALT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mrs Travers. It's alright. Mr Banks is going to be all right. I promise. Pamela nods in gratitude, but cannot contain her sobs. It all pouring from her now, in one immense catharsis. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. It's just that-- I can't, I can't abide cartoons! We stay on her face as we bring up the final song of the film: Let's Go Fly A Kite. The audience around her are smiling, laughing, singing along. Pamela, the tears, sile now, still pouring down her cheeks as she slowly begins t mouth along with the lyrics. And in her head one final image appears. Travers gaze falls upon Ginty, outside his bedroom window sweeping. Their eyes meet for a brief moment, an unspoken understanding of what is to come, before his close with tiredness.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Never. I promise. I will never lose you. DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow of an umbrella leaves the ten-year-old Ginty sitting in the lush grass, arms wrapped tightly around he chest, face to the sky as a smile breaks free across her face.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winds in the East Mist coming in-- The shadow of an umbrella, floats higher and higher-- TRAVERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Like something is brewing, about to begin-- And further and further-- TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't put me finger on what lies in STORE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We give chase but cannot catch up-- TRAVERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I feel what's to happen, all HAPPENED BEFORE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the umbrella floats up, up, up into the atmosphere an AWAY-- FADE OUT: END
